answer_html: That means there are two solutions for when \(\displaystyle f'(x)=0\).
answer_latex:
That means there are
two solutions for when $\displaystyle f'(x)=0$.
hints_html:
The derivative was computed in part (b):

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(x) = \left(3x^2 + 4x + 1\right)\cdot e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3}.\end{aligned}\]

Now set the derivative and solve. This can be done either by factoring or using the quadratic formula.

hints_raw:
The derivative was computed in [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH110/December_2013/Question_06_(b)|part (b)]]:

:<math>\displaystyle f'(x) = \left(3x^2 + 4x + 1\right)\cdot e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3}.</math>

Now set the derivative and solve. This can be done either by factoring or using the quadratic formula.
question: 6 (c)
sols_html:
Recall that

\(\displaystyle f'(x) = \left(3x^2 + 4x + 1\right)\cdot e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3}.\)

From part (a), we know that \(e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3}\neq 0\). That implies that \(\displaystyle f'(x) = 0\) when \(3x^2 + 4x + 1=0\). Factoring, we get \((3x+1)(x+1)=0\), which means \(x=-\frac{1}{3},-1\). That means there are two solutions for when \(\displaystyle f'(x)=0\).
sols_latex:
Recall that

$\displaystyle f'(x) = \left(3x^2 + 4x + 1\right)\cdot e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3}.$

From
{part
(a)}, we know that $e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3}\neq 0$. That implies that
$\displaystyle f'(x) = 0$ when $3x^2 + 4x + 1=0$. Factoring, we get
$(3x+1)(x+1)=0$, which means $x=-\frac{1}{3},-1$. That means there are
two solutions for when $\displaystyle f'(x)=0$.
sols_raw:
Recall that

<math>\displaystyle f'(x) = \left(3x^2 + 4x + 1\right)\cdot e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3}.</math>

From [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH110/December_2013/Question_06_(a)|part (a)]], we know that <math>e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3}\neq 0</math>. That implies that <math>\displaystyle f'(x) = 0</math> when <math>3x^2 + 4x + 1=0</math>. Factoring, we get <math>(3x+1)(x+1)=0</math>, which means <math>x=-\frac{1}{3},-1</math>. That means there are two solutions for when <math>\displaystyle f'(x)=0</math>.
statement_html:
Consider the function

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \dfrac{e^{\left(x^3\right)}e^{\left(2x^2\right)}e^{x}}{e^3}.\end{aligned}\]

(c) How many solutions are there to the equation \(\displaystyle f'(x)=0\)? Justify your answer.
statement_raw:
Consider the function: <math>f(x) = \dfrac{e^{\left(x^3\right)}e^{\left(2x^2\right)}e^{x}}{e^3}.</math>

'''(c)''' How many solutions are there to the equation <math>\displaystyle f'(x)=0</math>? Justify your answer.
